peopleea.forest_condition_accounts.indic.template:
# Forest Indicators Accounts

The indicator accounts compare the variable accounts in each location with their reference values for areas representing the same type of forest and bio-geographic region in 2000. When data for the year 2000 was not available, the closest temporal observation avaialble in the time series is taken as the reference. The combination of forest types @cite(EUCopernicusLMS2020) @cite(EEA2019) and bioregions @cite(EEA2015) results in 44 different classes @cite(MaesEtAl2023).

## Reference values
Reference values are defined to assess the healthiness of an area, by comparing the raw results of the variable against 
reference values for healthy forests and forests in bad conditions. The comparison is done within forests with similar characteristics. The upper bound threshold is set observing the healthiest forest, by using the 98th percentile of the value observed in areas representing healthy forests (Upper reference). By contrast, the unhealthiest forest conditions are represented by the 2nd percentile of the forest areas different than the protected areas with primary forests highly tree-covered (Lower reference). Protected areas with primary forests highly tree-cover are identified combining the data for protected areas @cite(UNEPIUCN2023), primary forests @cite(SabatiniEtAl2021) and for highly tree-covered areas @cite(EUCopernicusLMS2018).

### Rescaling of the variables
The 98th and 2nd percentiles, computed respectively in healthy and unhealthy reference areas, define the thresholds used to rescale the observed raw values of the variable into indicators ranging from 0 to 1.  

In order to assess the forest healthiness in a particular location, the value in the variable account is rescaled with the reference values for the same forest type and bioregion as follows:
Indicator account =  (Variable account – Lower reference) / (Upper reference – Lower reference). 

Values of the variable accounts below or above the reference ones are constrained to 0 and 1, respectively. Consequently, the indicator accounts range between 0 and 1, taking larger values when the area of interest is closer to the healthiest conditions.

### Reference areas
Different areas are considered to estimate good and degraded forests conditions. 

#### Reference areas representing healthy forests
These areas are used to identify forest considered in good health, so as to define the upper reference values of that variable. Forests considered in good conditions (the upper reference areas) must meet the following criteria:
 * being protected areas;
 * being primary forests, alias forests where the signs of human impacts, if any, are strongly blurred due to decades without forest management;
 * being highly tree-covered throughout the time series (areas that in the last year of the time series experienced a tree-covered density loss equal or higher than 5% from reference year are excluded).

Such criteria are observed based on the information of the following datasets:
 * Primary forests from the European Primary Forest Database v2.0 @cite(SabatiniEtAl2021)
 * Protected Areas from IUCN data @cite(UNEPIUCN2023)
 * Copernicus's High Resolution Layer Tree Cover Density @cite(Copernicus.highly.tree-covered.forest)

Results are obtained combining the following inputs by using, as consistently as possible, the year 2000 as the reference year, with exception of the information on the Tree-cover density, whose earliest observation is in the year 2012. Whenever a forest lacks to meet any of the listed criteria, it was not considered as an area of reference for good condition.

### Reference values: upper and lower thresholds
 * The upper (healthier conditions) reference threshold was set at the 98th percentile value observed in the reference healthy areas, for each type of forest, for each variable. 
 * The lower (worse conditions) reference threshold was set at the 2nd percentile value observed in the rest of the forest area: (Total forest area - healthy reference area).
 * The percentile might be inverted in case the healthier conditions correspond to lower values in the original dataset (raw variable).

peopleea.forest_condition_accounts.index.template:
# Forest Condition Index

The Forest Condition Index quantifies the forest health by synthetizing the information from indicator accounts representing different forest conditions. The index is composed of one indicator account per Ecosystem Typology Class (ETC) as variables from the same class may be highly correlated. Specifically, the index involves the Net Difference Water Index (NDWI), Soil Organic Carbon (SOC), Threatened forest bird species diversity (TFBSD), Above-Ground Biomass (AGB), Net Primary Production (NPP), Burn severity (BS) and Forest connectivity (FC). Given the low correlation of BS with NPP, both variables have been included despite pertaining to the same ETC.

In order to obtain the indicator accounts, the index uses their weighted average. The weights for indicator accounts are determined according to their spatial resolution (i.e. the size of the smallest feature detected by a satellite sensor or displayed in a satellite image, usually expressed as a single value measuring the length of one side of a square), temporal resolution (i.e. the total amount of years in a dataset), temporal frequency (i.e. the availability of temporal observations over the same period) and dataset quality (referring to the proximity of the latest year to the present). In particular, indicator accounts are ranked according to each of these categories. Larger quantities of these criteria are associated to better representation of the ecological conditions and, consequently, report indicators a higher position. The relative sum of the indicator accounts positions results in their index weight. When data of several indicators coincides in one aspect, each indicator is attributed the average of the positions they would represent. For example, if there are three indicator accounts that should be ranked 7, they will be assigned 6 since it is the average of the positions these variables represent (5th, 6th and 7th). Positions and weights attributed to indicator accounts are detailed in the table below:

| Indicator | Spatial resolution | Temporal resolution | Temporal frequency | Dataset quality | Weight |
|:---------:|:------------------:|:-------------------:|:------------------:|:---------------:|:------:|
|    NDWI   |          6         |          7          |          7         |       6.5       |  0.27  |
|    SOC    |          2         |          1          |          1         |        2        |  0.07  |
|   TBFSD   |          1         |         3.5         |          3         |        1        |  0.10  |
|    AGB    |          6         |         3.5         |          3         |       4.5       |  0.18  |
|    NPP    |          4         |          5          |          6         |       6.5       |  0.22  |
|     FC    |          6         |          2          |          3         |        3        |  0.16  |
The formulation of the resulting Forest Condition Index is the following:
Forest Condition Index = 
(NDWI x 0.27) + (SOC x 0.07) + (TBFSD x 0.10) + (AGB x 0.18) + (NPP x 0.22) + (FC x 0.16)
For areas where Soil Organic Carbon is missing, because of dataset coverage, the index is calculated redistributing the weights:
Forest Condition Index = 
(NDWI x 0.31) + (TBFSD x 0.11) + (AGB x 0.19) + (NPP x 0.24) + (FC x 0.15)

peopleea.forest_condition_accounts.maes_.template:
# Forest Indicators Accounts by Maes et al. (2023) standards
Indicator accounts measure the proximity in the forest condition of an area to those representative of degraded and primary forests in the year 2000 for the same forest type and biogeographic zone in order to assess the health of the area of interest. The combination of the forest classes @cite(EUCopernicusLMS2020) @cite(EUCopernicusLMS2020CLC18) and the biogeographic zones @cite(EEA2016) leads to the presence of 44 different classes.

## Reference values
Reference values are defined to assess the healthiness of an area, by comparing the raw values of the variable against the reference values from healthy forests and forests in bad conditions. This comparison is done across forests of the same type and biogeographic zone.
The upper bound threshold, representing the healthiest forest conditions, is taken from primary forests @cite(SabatiniEtAl2021) or least disturbed forests from protected areas @cite(UNEPIUCN2023) when the former do not exist, retaining the areas with tree cover loss lower than 5% @cite(HansenEtAl2013). The lower bound threshold, representing the most degraded conditions, corresponds to the minimum value of the distribution.  

### Rescaling of the variables
The maximum and minimum values, obtained respectively from primary and degraded reference areas, define the thresholds used to rescale the observed raw values of the variable into indicators ranging from 0 to 1.  
In order to assess the forest healthiness in a particular location, the value in the variable account is rescaled with the reference values for the same forest type and bioregion as follows:
Indicator account =  (Variable account – Lower reference) / (Upper reference – Lower reference). 
Values of the variable accounts below or above the reference ones are constrained to 0 and 1, respectively. Consequently, the indicator accounts range between 0 and 1, taking larger values when the area of interest is closer to the healthiest conditions.

### Reference areas
Reference values for healthy forest conditions are extracted from areas considered to be minimally disturbed by anthropogenic actions, which are mainly primary forest. By contrast, reference values of degraded conditions are extracted from the remaining areas.  

#### Reference areas representing healthy forests
These areas are used to identify forests considered in good health, so as to define the upper reference values of that variable. In particular, primary forests are considered as reference areas for upper reference values to show the best forest conditions @cite(SabatiniEtAl2021). In case, primary forests do not exist, the three classes of most protected areas are considered @cite(UNEPIUCN2023). In both cases, only forests with a tree cover loss @cite(HansenEtAl2013) lower than 5% from 2001 to 2020 with respect to 2000. 

### Reference values: upper and lower thresholds
 * The upper reference threshold (healthier conditions) corresponds to the maximum value of the variable observed in the reference healthy areas for each type of forest and biogeographic zone. 
 * The lower reference threshold (worse conditions) was set at the minimum value of the variable for each type of forest and biogeographic zone.

# Forest Condition Index by Maes et al. (2023) standards  
  
The Forest Condition Index quantifies the forest health by synthesising the information from indicator accounts representing different forest conditions. The indicators composing the index aim to fully represent all the components of ecosystems (abiotic, biotic and landscape). They are selected considering their relevance, their direct relationship to forest condition and the availability of data for their measurement. Specifically, the index involves the Net Difference Water Index (NDWI), Soil Organic Carbon (SOC), Threatened forest bird species diversity (TFBSD), Tree cover density (TCD), Forest productivity (NDVI),  Forest connectivity (FC) and Landscape naturalness (LN).  

In order to obtain a unique assessment on the forest condition, the index uses the weighted average of indicator accounts. The weights for indicator accounts are assigned based on their capacity to represent the ecosystem structure (intrinsic relevance), the ecosystem services provided (instrumental relevance), the changes in forest condition derived from external factors (directionality meaning) and the anthropogenic repercussion (sensibility to human influence) as well as on their adequacy to the SEEA EA framework (framework adequacy). Indicators are ranked between 1 (lowest position) and 7 (highest position) regarding each of these aspects, being attributed higher positions with better conditions. Having an overall better positioning reports indicators a larger weight in the index. In particular, the relative sum of the indicator positions results in their index weight. Positions and weights attributed to indicator accounts are detailed in the table below, which corresponds to the Supplementary Table 9 in @cite(MaesEtAl2023).

|          Conceptual criteria            | NDWI | SOC | TFBSD | TCD | NDVI | FC | LN |
|:----------------------------------------:|:--------:|:-----:|:-------:|:------:|:------:|:---:|:---:|
| Intrinsic relevance                       |     1     |     3   |     7     |    6   |     2    |  5   |  4  |
| Instrumental relevance              |     4     |     5   |     3     |    6   |     7    |  2   |  1  |
| Directional meaning                   |     1     |     3   |     7     |    5   |     2    |  4   |  6  |
| Sensibility to human influence |     2     |     1   |     7     |    6   |     3    |  5   |  4  |
| Framework conformity              |     3     |     5   |     7     |    6   |     4    |  2   |  1  |
| Sum of the ranks                         |    11    |   17   |    31    |   29  |   18  | 18  | 16 |
| Weights                                         |  0.08  | 0.12  |   0.22  | 0.21 | 0.13 |0.13|0.11|

The formulation of the resulting Forest Condition Index is the following:
Forest Condition Index = 
(NDWI x 0.08) + (SOC x 0.12) + (TBFSD x 0.22) + (TCD x 0.21) + (NDVI x 0.13) + (FC x 0.13) + (LN x 0.11)
For areas where Soil Organic Carbon is missing, because of dataset coverage, the index is calculated redistributing the weights:
Forest Condition Index = 
(NDWI x 0.10) + (TBFSD x 0.26) + (TCD x 0.23) + (NDVI x 0.15) + (FC x 0.14) + (LN x 0.12)
